Stable snowpack conditions are observed on slopes with a N/NE aspect in the region.
Because of the warm spells throughout the course of this month, with frequent thawing and then refreezing, the surface of the snow has a thin crust in many places. Below that there is a layer which probably formed from the small snowfall and blowing snow last week, below which there is yet another, slightly thicker and harder crust, which probably formed during the previous melt-freeze cycle earlier this month. Below that is a thicker, fairly homogenous layer, that extends all the way to the start of the mountain pine below (this snowpit was dug in a location with dense mountain pine underneath, so it is only around 110 cm deep). This thick layer consists of sugary snow crystals all throughout it, and is probably the combination of a few separate layers, which have slowly combined into 1, as a result of settling of the snow over time. At the top the snow is more sugary and softer (fist) and as you go deeper down the snow becomes less sugary and a bit harder (4 fingers) and more stable. The potential concern at the moment is the top part of this layer. The snow there is of a sugary consistency, but the bonds are fairly strong, and it takes until around CT27 to start to get a breakup in them. The breakup of the top part of this layer starts at that time and continues until the end of the compression test, but no smooth sliding is observed - we observe more of a gradual breakup of the snow there into small chunks.
Despite the high temperatures and sun during the day on 19.02.2022, slopes with a northerly component have not become too soft or wet and in fact remained fairly hard and unpleasant to ski. Therefore, the risk of wet snow avalanches on these slopes above 2000 meters has likely passed, as it was not present yesterday and from today (20.02.2022) temperatures have begun to fall and will stay this way the next few days (conditions may have been different on 19.02 on southern slopes). The snowpack is stable on these slope orientations at the moment, but it may change with the snowfall predicted for this week.
No avalanche activity is observed in the region. There is a massive in depth and very wide snow cornice on the northeastern side of Ismailitsa Peak, which may become dangerous in the springtime. There is some "sahara sand" and therefore slighly "redish" snow observed on some nearby slopes as well, probably from the storm last week.
